channel.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
channel.description: As name. If I do not have an answer, I will do my best to find an answer. Other languages are acceptable as well, but I can answer questions most quickly about the ones that I have listed. I am also open to questions about computer science in general.

item.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“Native^, post:30, topic:453461”]Ok, got a question about SQL. How would I check if a value already exists in the table?
The scenario is like, the player logs in, some SQL stuff happens that checks if the name already exists, if yes, it fetches the data from the database, if not, it creates a new row with the username, password and shit.
It’s probably a bad idea to just get all the names from the database and loop through them.[/quote]

Some examples using a table named ‘users’ with two columns: ‘id’ and ‘name’

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM users WHERE users.name = 'Native^'; -- if this is greater than 0, it exists SELECT users.id FROM users WHERE users.name = 'Native^'; -- if this returns an ID, it exists -- could come up with a few more contrived examples but those are the most straightforward

Play around with this: http://dev.mysql.com/downloads/workbench/ (or the SQL client of your choice for whatever flavor of SQL you are using).

[hr]

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:31, topic:453461”]I have a question.

Some masterminds say that C++ is the king of all programming languages, the superior language. I, as a dedicated java enthusiast, would like to know if it’s maybe time to abandon java and start writing the clearly superior C++? Could you express your thoughts on this?[/quote]

C++ has tons of features. I do not have much experience with it.

That being said, # of features != superiority. You can produce very efficient code with C++, but is execution speed your greatest concern for all areas of your project? My guess is probably not.

There are many other things to consider - community support, standard libraries, package management, language syntax, the purpose of your project, the size of your team, the number of mistakes your team will make with the language, the rate at which your requirements change, how enjoyable the language is to work with, etc.

I tend to develop with a scripting language (Ruby, Python) and only optimize the parts of the application that need it the most. You can do that in a systems language - both Python and Ruby have decent support for C extensions. If you are interested in learning a systems language, give C a shot. D and Go are also interesting.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything

item.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:35, topic:453461”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=556302.msg4078051#msg4078051 date=1345061729]

Ok, got a question about SQL. How would I check if a value already exists in the table?
The scenario is like, the player logs in, some SQL stuff happens that checks if the name already exists, if yes, it fetches the data from the database, if not, it creates a new row with the username, password and shit.
It’s probably a bad idea to just get all the names from the database and loop through them.

http://www.techonthenet.com/sql/exists.php
[/quote]
it tells you that way is inefficient

why not just use WHERE clause?

SELECT * from users_tables WHERE username = ‘user’ LIMIT 1;

then u can run your if statement

if($sqlresult){
echo ‘username registered’ }

otherwise INSERT query to add user to the users_table[/quote]
I’m using jdbc (java), not php.

got it already.

public static boolean check(String name) throws SQLException { Statement s; s = connection.createStatement(); ResultSet set = s .executeQuery("SELECT * FROM playerdb.players WHERE username='" + name + "'"); return set.next(); }

Read full topic

item.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:27, topic:453461”]Vrunk, your description of volatile isn’t right. It doesn’t describe behavior of accessing transient variables, it describes accessing volatile variables, wherein a variable is expected to be read and written to at the same time. Volatile ensures that the variable is stored in memory shared between all threads, rather than being locally copied for each there (and therefore, if a thread decides to access and change that variable, it must wait until another thread has finished writing/reading it first).

Your use of the word transient is wrong and confusing in that description. :P[/quote]

Typo - fixed. Guess that’s what I get for trying to answer so many questions at once :). Thanks for the additional clarification as well.

Here’s some additional documentation on the volatile keyword (didn’t look hard enough yesterday):
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/essential/concurrency/atomic.html

It also seems to cause writes to have priority over all reads to a variable declared volatile.

Read full topic
item.source: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything

[quote=“Taharok, post:27, topic:453461”]Vrunk, your description of volatile isn’t right. It doesn’t describe behavior of accessing transient variables, it describes accessing volatile variables, wherein a variable is expected to be read and written to at the same time. Volatile ensures that the variable is stored in memory shared between all threads, rather than being locally copied for each there (and therefore, if a thread decides to access and change that variable, it must wait until another thread has finished writing/reading it first).

Your use of the word transient is wrong and confusing in that description. :P[/quote]
Like static, but between threads. And accessing is different.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Vrunk, your description of volatile isn’t right. It doesn’t describe behavior of accessing transient variables, it describes accessing volatile variables, wherein a variable is expected to be read and written to at the same time. Volatile ensures that the variable is stored in memory shared between all threads, rather than being locally copied for each there (and therefore, if a thread decides to access and change that variable, it must wait until another thread has finished writing/reading it first).

Your use of the word transient is wrong and confusing in that description.

item.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

=> 3
[hr]

[quote="wildskiller, post:9, topic:453461"]AtomicInt_ or Vrunk, if you could give me any advice for Java, what would it be?

BEST ADVICE YOU COULD POSSIBLE GIVE[/quote]
Best advice for Java... that's a pretty open ended question, but I'll give it a shot anyways.

[ul][li]Learn the collections framework - Sets, Lists, Maps. After you are comfortable with the purpose of each one, move on to learn about specific implementations. Pick a simple project and use one of each. Document why you chose the specific implementation (think!).[/li]
[li]Don't get too caught up in design patterns, optimization, or concurrency (at least if you are starting out). Focus on the problem you are trying to solve, and pick the best tools as you go along.[/li][/ul]


[hr]

[quote="luke4life, post:12, topic:453461"]Just a few things, it might be off-topic but ohwell.

What is the best to learn to make RSPS? Java,javascript or what?

and can anybody link me to something like a tut? or just something about java. cause i'd like to learn java and start making my own server.

thanks.[/quote]

[ul][li]Java. If you want to mess around with private servers, you should start out by obtaining the source, setting up the project, compiling it, and running it. After that, try implementing a chat command or something.
[/li]
[li]If you are more interested in website design, you should give jQuery or Prototype a shot (JavaScript libraries). You could put together a simple website and hook it up to a MySQL database. Try implementing a high scores page.[/li][/ul]


[hr]

[quote="xxxtilllyxxx, post:18, topic:453461"]When would reflection be needed / used? What is the "transient, volatile, and protected" modifiers used for?[/quote]

[ul][li]Reflection is used to examine / modify the run time behavior of applications on the JVM. In other words, you can use it to see (or change) things at run time that you normally wouldn't be able to. This is useful for debuggers, IDEs, or whatever else you'd like to do. It has some performance overhead.[/li]
[li][i]transient[/i] means that a field's value is not written to the serialized representation of the object upon serialization. Upon deserialization (reading the object back into memory), each transient field is initialized to its default value.[/li]
[li][i]volatile[/i] is used by the programmer to indicate that a field will be modified by multiple threads. It is used by the JVM to ensure that all reads and writes to [s]transient[/s] [i]volatile[/i] fields are done correctly. I am not too familiar with it past that.[/li]
[li][i]protected[/i] is an access modifier - it determines what level of access other classes have to fields and methods. [i]protected[/i] members are accessible by the class, package, and subclass. A stranger example is when [i]no modifier[/i] is given, which grants access to only the class and package (but not subclasses).[/li][/ul]

=> 3
[hr]

[quote=“wildskiller, post:9, topic:453461”]AtomicInt_ or Vrunk, if you could give me any advice for Java, what would it be?

BEST ADVICE YOU COULD POSSIBLE GIVE[/quote]
Best advice for Java… that’s a pretty open ended question, but I’ll give it a shot anyways.

[ul][li]Learn the collections framework - Sets, Lists, Maps. After you are comfortable with the purpose of each one, move on to learn about specific implementations. Pick a simple project and use one of each. Document why you chose the specific implementation (think!).[/li]
[li]Don’t get too caught up in design patterns, optimization, or concurrency (at least if you are starting out). Focus on the problem you are trying to solve, and pick the best tools as you go along.[/li][/ul]

[hr]

[quote=“luke4life, post:12, topic:453461”]Just a few things, it might be off-topic but ohwell.

What is the best to learn to make RSPS? Java,javascript or what?

and can anybody link me to something like a tut? or just something about java. cause i’d like to learn java and start making my own server.

thanks.[/quote]

[ul][li]Java. If you want to mess around with private servers, you should start out by obtaining the source, setting up the project, compiling it, and running it. After that, try implementing a chat command or something.
[/li]
[li]If you are more interested in website design, you should give jQuery or Prototype a shot (JavaScript libraries). You could put together a simple website and hook it up to a MySQL database. Try implementing a high scores page.[/li][/ul]

[hr]

xxxtilllyxxx:

When would reflection be needed / used? What is the “transient, volatile, and protected” modifiers used for?

[ul][li]Reflection is used to examine / modify the run time behavior of applications on the JVM. In other words, you can use it to see (or change) things at run time that you normally wouldn’t be able to. This is useful for debuggers, IDEs, or whatever else you’d like to do. It has some performance overhead.[/li]
[li]transient means that a field’s value is not written to the serialized representation of the object upon serialization. Upon deserialization (reading the object back into memory), each transient field is initialized to its default value.[/li]
[li]volatile is used by the programmer to indicate that a field will be modified by multiple threads. It is used by the JVM to ensure that all reads and writes to transient volatile fields are done correctly. I am not too familiar with it past that.[/li]
[li]protected is an access modifier - it determines what level of access other classes have to fields and methods. protected members are accessible by the class, package, and subclass. A stranger example is when no modifier is given, which grants access to only the class and package (but not subclasses).[/li][/ul]

Read full topic

item.title: Java, Ruby, SQL, JavaScript - Ask me anything
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

xxxtilllyxxx:

When would reflection be needed / used? What is the “transient, volatile, and protected” modifiers used for?

volatile = http://www.javamex.com/tutorials/synchronization_volatile.shtml

Practically synchronization of a variable between threads.

protected is an access modifier that only gives extended classes access/itself.

transient is used for serialization and that variable will not be included.

Read full topic

dummies

Java Keywords - dummies

The Java programming language has 50 keywords. Each keyword has a specific meaning in the language. You can’t use a keyword for anything other than its pre-assigned meaning. The following table lists Java’s keywords. Keyword What It Does abstract...

item.dc:creator: @Scape-JAVA Scape-JAVA
item.description:
@Scape-JAVA wrote:

[quote=“luke4life, post:12, topic:453461”]Just a few things, it might be off-topic but ohwell.

Good luck :).
